unnormalised: Okay, so last week, I was thinking about how much we spend on, like, *stuff*. You know? That new phone (Rs. 30,000, ouch!), eating out (easily ₹500 a pop), even that daily chai (Rs. 15 from the tapri outside my office). It adds up!
normalised: Okay, so last week, I was thinking about how much we spend on, like, stuff. You know? That new phone (rupee thirty thousand, ouch!), eating out (easily rupee five hundred a pop), even that daily chai (rupee fifteen from the tapri outside my office). It adds up!

unnormalised: And then I thought, what if we diverted just a tiny, tiny fraction of that spending towards something good? Like, proper good. Not just feeling-good-for-five-minutes good, but actually making a difference.
normalised: And then I thought, what if we diverted just a tiny, tiny fraction of that spending towards something good? Like, proper good. Not just feeling-good-for-five-minutes good, but actually making a difference.

unnormalised: I was scrolling through Insta and saw this campaign by GiveIndia – they're aiming to raise ₹2 lakh for underprivileged kids' education. Two lakh sounds like a LOT, right? But then I calculated, if just 1000 of us donated Rs. 200 each, BOOM! Goal achieved. Makes you think, doesn't it?
normalised: I was scrolling through I-n-s-t-a and saw this campaign by GiveIndia – they're aiming to raise rupee two lakh for underprivileged kids' education. Two lakh sounds like a L-O-T, right? But then I calculated, if just one thousand of us donated rupee two hundred each, B-O-O-M! Goal achieved. Makes you think, doesn't it?

unnormalised: My building society is planning a donation drive for an old age home too. They're asking for Rs. 501 per person, which honestly, is less than what I spend on a single weekend brunch. I'm thinking I might even chip in an extra Rs. 100 to cover someone else who might be struggling.
normalised: My building society is planning a donation drive for an old age home too. They're asking for rupee five hundred and one per person, which honestly, is less than what I spend on a single weekend brunch. I'm thinking I might even chip in an extra rupee one hundred to cover someone else who might be struggling.

unnormalised: And it doesn't even have to be cash, right? My dadi always says, *“Anna daan maha daan”* (food donation is the greatest donation). So, maybe we can donate that extra bag of rice (5 kg?) that’s been sitting in the cupboard for ages to a local NGO?
normalised: And it doesn't even have to be cash, right? My dadi always says, *“Anna daan maha daan”* (food donation is the greatest donation). So, maybe we can donate that extra bag of rice (five kilogram?) that’s been sitting in the cupboard for ages to a local N-G-O?

unnormalised: I remember last year, during the floods in Chennai, my office organized a collection drive. People donated clothes, blankets (remember those winter sales where blankets were going for like, Rs. 399?), and even medicines. It was incredible to see the community come together.
normalised: I remember last year, during the floods in Chennai, my office organized a collection drive. People donated clothes, blankets (remember those winter sales where blankets were going for like, rupee three hundred and ninety nine?), and even medicines. It was incredible to see the community come together.

unnormalised: Plus, a lot of charities offer tax exemptions under section 80G. So donating ₹5000 could actually save you some money on taxes! Win-win, right? You do good and the taxman gives you a little break. Check with your CA about the details, of course.
normalised: Plus, a lot of charities offer tax exemptions under section eighty G. So donating rupee five thousand could actually save you some money on taxes! Win-win, right? You do good and the taxman gives you a little break. Check with your C-A about the details, of course.

unnormalised: So yeah, my takeaway? Let's be a little more mindful about where our money goes. Maybe skip that expensive coffee one day (saving Rs. 200!), or finally declutter your closet and donate those clothes. Every little bit counts, and together, we can actually make a real difference.
normalised: So yeah, my takeaway? Let's be a little more mindful about where our money goes. Maybe skip that expensive coffee one day (saving rupee two hundred!), or finally declutter your closet and donate those clothes. Every little bit counts, and together, we can actually make a real difference.

unnormalised: Anyways, that’s my two paisa. What are some charities you guys support? Let me know in the comments! I’m always looking for good causes to contribute to. And hey, maybe we can even start a little donation chain together!
normalised: Anyways, that’s my two paisa. What are some charities you guys support? Let me know in the comments! I’m always looking for good causes to contribute to. And hey, maybe we can even start a little donation chain together!
